learning_outcomes.description: Engage critically and constructively with frameworks, legislation, philosophies of care and contemporary issues associated with disability to advocate in an everchanging landscape.
Describe and interpret appropriate assessments across the ICF framework to identify communication and swallowing support needs for people with a disability.
Design evidence-based speech pathology intervention to address person- and family-centred goals of people with disability.
Explain the application of augmentative and alternative communication options for people with complex communication needs and their communication partners.
Work in a professional team, including the provision of effective, and constructive feedback, to support communication and swallowing for people with disabilities.
Describe the key characteristics of disabilities that impact communication and swallowing across the lifespan.

assessments.task_description:
After attending the Lived Experience of Disability Panel, students are required to submit one (1) video reflection. The panel discussion will inform this assessment and requires students to critically reflect on the perspectives shared by the panellists.

In this assessment, students are expected to move beyond a descriptive summary of the panel and instead integrate insights from the discussion with relevant course concepts related to disability across the lifespan, communication, and professional speech pathology practice. Students should also reflect on how this learning will influence their future clinical reasoning and practice.

A detailed task description will be uploaded to the course Blackboard site.

assessments.task_description:
Each student is required to complete an assignment on people with disability who present with communication and/or feeding support needs relating to disability. With reference to the provided background information, case data, and relevant literature, students will discuss the communication assessment results, provide a diagnostic summary, and present an interprofessional management protocol based on the International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health (ICF) developed by the World Health Organization (WHO, 2001).

learning_activities.topic:
Online self-directed learning modules (self-directed learning)

A series of weekly online modules will provide information on the holistic management of evidence-based practice for people with disability across the lifespan. The self-directed learning module content will cover a broad range of topics, including contemporary and evolving views of disability, the role of speech pathologists and interprofessional teams in supporting people with disability, supporting people with lifelong conditions (e.g., cerebral palsy, intellectual disability, cleft palate, hearing loss), and supporting clients with complex communication and swallowing disabilities (both assessment and intervention). The online modules will also cover Augmentative and Alternative Communication (AAC) for people with disability, including an overview of what AAC is and who benefits from it, AAC trial considerations and implementation, including the role of Key Word Sign (KWS).

learning_activities.topic:
Weekly on campus tutorials

Tutorials will be conducted from weeks 1-13 of semester and will incorporate inquiry-based learning and small group discussion to further explore speech pathology approaches to the holistic and evidence-based management of people with disability across the lifespan. On campus tutorials will include practical sessions delivered by experts in Augmentative and Alternative Communication (AAC) and Key Word Sign (KWS) to support students' understanding of best practice when working with clients with disability.

Tutorials have been designed for experiential learning; therefore, students are expected to attend and actively participate in all tutorials. It is essential that students prepare for tutorials by completing the online self-paced learning modules and associated preparation activities. As students will be working in small groups during this learning activity, tutorials will not be recorded.

learning_activities.topic:
Lived Experience of Disability Lecture

In this learning activity, you will explore disability through direct engagement with a person with disability and their treating professionals. The session is designed to centre lived experience and professional perspectives, providing insight into how disability is experienced, supported, and understood in everyday life and clinical practice.

By attending this activity, you will have the opportunity to listen to personal stories, learn about the roles of different health professionals, and reflect on how collaboration, communication, and respect underpin person‑centred care. This interactive panel-lecture also provides a safe and respectful space for you to ask questions and engage in meaningful dialogue with the panellists.

Note*: Due to the nature of this activity and the availability of the panellists, it will be scheduled on a Tuesday, outside typical tutorial hours.
